XIII. 1 tSolent interdum historici causam interfectorum hostium, captorum praesertim aut supplicum, referre aut ad talionem, aut ad pertinaciam in resistendo : sed hae eausae, ut alibi distinximus, suasoriae magis sunt quam justificae. Nam talio justa et proprie dicta in eandem personam quae deliquit exercenda est, ut intelligi potest ex his quae de poenae commu- nicatione dicta sunt supra. Contra vero in bello plerumque id quod talio dicitur in malum redundat eorum quorum in eo quod accusatur nulla est culpa. XIII. 1 Historians sometimes mention, as the cause of putting to death enemies, especially captives or suppliants, the rule of retalia- tion, or their obstinacy in resisting: but these causes, as we have elsewhere explained, are rather suasory than justificatory. For reta* lintion, which is just, and properly so called, must be exercised against the same person who has offended: as may be understood from what we have said of the punishment of accessorieS. But on the other hand, it commonly happens that what is called. retaliation, falls upon those who have no share in the blame which is charged. The practice is, that those who are defeated, are made to suffer what they had in- tended to inflict3 and that by such inflictions, the enemy are restrained from omi-bearing severities. So Diodorus.
